title: 114_s2392
content: The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" restricts MA organizations from removing providers without cause starting in 2017. Cause for removal includes medical negligence or violation of legal or contractual requirements. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" prohibits MA organizations from removing providers without cause, such as medical negligence or violation of legal or contractual requirements, starting in 2017. Cost to an MA organization due to a provider's participation in a plan network is not a valid reason for removal. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" prohibits MA organizations from removing providers without cause, starting in 2017. An MA organization can only remove a provider from a plan network for specific reasons before the annual coordinated election period, with a notice and appeal process in place. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" mandates a fair notice and appeal process for the removal of providers from MA plan networks, starting in 2017. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" requires a fair notice and appeal process for provider removal from MA plan networks, with specific procedures outlined for termination or suspension of provider contracts. Participants must receive at least 60 days' notice before provider removal. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" mandates that MA organizations must give written notification at least 60 days before removing a provider from their network. The notification should include details of alternative in-network providers offering similar services. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" requires MA organizations to provide written notification at least 60 days before removing a provider from their network. The notification must include information on alternative in-network providers, options for continuing medical treatment, and customer service contact numbers for plan changes. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" mandates MA organizations to notify members at least 60 days in advance before removing a provider from their network. The notification should include details on alternative in-network providers and options for continued medical care. Additionally, the MA plan must ensure continuity of care for individuals receiving services from the removed provider. Beginning in 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations must provide transparency in the measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This includes disclosing information on quality measures on their website and in annual bid submissions. This does not affect a provider's ability to decline participation in an MA plan network. In 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations must disclose details on provider network modifications, quality measures, and efficiency. The information should include specifications, methodology, sample size, and other relevant data determined by the Secretary. Sanctions for noncompliance are outlined in the Social Security Act. The Social Security Act outlines sanctions for noncompliance with Medicare Advantage organization disclosures. The Act also requires the Medicare Advantage Compare Tool to consider individual preferences and utilization needs within a year of enactment. SEC. 3. NETWORK ADEQUACY. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, types of services, provider availability, and location when establishing a plan network. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations must ensure timely provision of care by providers in their MA plans. The Secretary will apply network access adequacy standards with input from various stakeholders, and organizations must certify plan details annually. Medicare Advantage organizations must certify that providers in their MA plans can offer required services and meet enrollees' needs. They must report average wait times for care and utilization of out-of-network providers annually. The Medicare Advantage organization must certify the accuracy of provider directories for each plan offered. The Secretary ensures network adequacy guidelines are met at least once every 3 years. The Medicare Advantage organization must certify provider directories' accuracy for each plan offered. Network adequacy guidelines must be met every 3 years or when a material change in the network occurs. Section 1857(g)(1)(K) of the Social Security Act is amended to include additional provisions.
